titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mr Plummer and a Mr Gair of Providence called upon me this morning— I employed the day, with the exception of a walk before Breakfast, and one before dinner, in writing; and the Evening in hearing and amusing Charles— He was unwell. I read several Chapters in the second Volume of Coelebs.

2. Visits from Mr Montreal and Mr Delprat— Montreal has seen a person from Moscow who left it the 20th: of last Month; five days after the French entered— But he declines telling any thing that was passing there.— Mr Delprat brought me a slip from an English Newspaper containing the Instructions to American Privateers; and an Act of Congress to prohibit American vessels from trading with the Enemies of the United States— There is this day a Publication here by Authority; to assure the public that St: Petersburg is in no danger of being taken by the Enemy; and explaining the motives for taking now the precaution of packing up and sending away the necessary things—which they are doing in open day at the Hermitage and the public Offices— There are also three encouraging Bulletins of News from the Army; and reports still more encouraging.

3. Walks before Breakfast and before dinner.— The rest of the day chiefly employed writing and reading— As the Nights lengthen I find it practicable again to retire at an early hour, between ten and eleven, and consequently to rise about six in the morning— From this time untill ten or eleven in the Morning, our usual breakfasting hour, I find the most useful part of the day for employment. From dinner time untill the close of the day time hangs a little upon my hands, for my weak eyes, and a sort of sluggish drowsiness which I cannot overcome, make it almost impossible; or at least useless to read.

4. Walk, an hour and a half before Breakfast, and an equal time before dinner— Met Mr Krehmer who left his Droshky, and spoke to me. Read prayers and Sterne’s Sermon; upon the search after Happiness— I also read Sermons 7 and 8
of Vol 9. of the English Preacher— On the Honourable character of an upright Magistrate, by Atterbury, and on St: Paul’s behaviour before the Civil Magistrate, by Hoadly— This last is a high-toned whig pamphlet, preached at an Assize.— It is very ingenious, and as to the argument perfectly conclusive. Its object is to refute the opinion that the doctrine of passive Obedience was countenanced by St: Paul— It is very strange that such an opinion should ever have been entertained— In perusing the controversies which have arisen from scriptural expressions, I am often surprized to see how much sagacity, how much learning, how much keen and powerful intellect it has often been necessary to employ, to put down the grossest and most flagrant absurdities— In the Evening I finished reading Miss More’s Coelebs, a book of some merit, containing many just observations upon manners and some well drawn delineations of character— Perhaps with too large a dose of religion

5. Mr Harris called on me this morning, and asked Mr Smith and me to dine with him this day, which we did— Prince Koslofsky, Mr Poletica, and Mr Krehmer, were the company;—Mr Rapatel was to have been there, but was sent for to dine with the Emperor— He came in after dinner; as did a son of Baron Rall, and Mr Slade— Mr Rapatel was in his Uniform, and is to go to-morrow to join one of the armies— The abbé Fremont who lives with Mr Harris, was at table, and obliged to hear all the bitterness of Prince Koslofsky and of Mr Poletica against the French; it was as inveterate as might be expected from the rancorous War they are waging—the Prince is appointed Minister to the Court of Sardinia, where he was formerly Chargé d’Affairs— Notwithstanding his abhorrence of the French, he manifestly takes pleasure in being reminded that he is a member of the Legion of Honour. He professes to think himself disgraced by it, but the complacency with which he returns to the idea, shews that it is a disgrace, which he would be sorry to lose. He says that Prince Kurakin is still detained at Paris. That before Count Lauriston went away he had officially declared that Prince Kurakin had not only received his Passports, but that every attention had been shewn him to facilitate his journey— And yet that now there were letters here received from Prince Kurakin, and dated 30. August, complaining that he had not then received and could not obtain his Passports. We had our double windows this day put up— I began again to hear Charles read in the Morning.

6. Morning visits from Mr Montreal, and from Mr J. W. Smith, and Mr Lawler, who have just arrived from Archangel— They found no positive knowledge of the surrender of Moscow to the French, untill they arrived here— Their intention was to have gone to Moscow; but on their arrival at Wologda they heard sufficient to induce them to come on directly to St: Petersburg. Charles went with Mr Smith this Evening to the theatre.

7. Morning visits from Mr Montreal, and from Mr Lewis with Mr Redwood— I sent to request an interview with the Minister of Finance Mr Gourieff, in consequence of letters I received yesterday from Mr Hazard and from a Captain Knox, Master of an American vessel, who is arrested at Archangel— Mr Gourieff appointed to-morrow, at Noon to see me.— Took my walks before Breakfast and before dinner— The rest of the day, chiefly employed in writing— Spent the Evening, playing with Charles.

8. I received this morning from Mr Laval a note with the form of a Certificate of his life, which there being now here no French Minister or Consul, he requested me to execute— I called a few minutes after twelve at Mr Gourieff’s, but he was not at home— I afterwards received from him a Note, mentioning that he had been unexpectedly called to Court, and desiring me to appoint an hour to-morrow, before Noon, or after seven in the Evening— I wrote him that I would call on him at 11 in the morning.— I returned Mr Poletica’s visit; but he was not at home— Went also to Mr Laval’s and to Baron Blome’s; both of whom were out. The weather being unusually fine, every body was abroad, and the streets and Boulevard were crowded with People.— I stopp’d, half an hour at Mr Etter’s new lodgings, and saw some more of his Antiquities.— After returning home I wrote part of a letter— Mrs Adams was very unwell the whole day, and this Evening quite ill— I read in Dugald Stewarts account of the life of Adam Smith.

9. At eleven O’Clock this morning according to appointment, I called upon the Minister of Finance Mr Gourieff, and stated to him the case of Captain Knox at Archangel, as represented to me by himself and by Mr Hazard— He came from Lisbon with a Cargo of Wines; but having a few prohibited Articles on board, they have not only been confiscated, but he has been arrested, and is still detained— I told Mr Gourieff that I could not pretend to interfere with the operation of the Laws of the Country; but that I hoped it might be possible to release this unfortunate man, who states that his offence was unintentional and arose solely from his ignorance that the articles were prohibited— He said he would enquire into the matter, which would he thought be adjusted with little difficulty— The Laws must necessarily be rigorous against the introduction of prohibited goods, but there were always cases to which some indulgence should be extended; and he should consider this as one of them; and do what was in his power to have the man discharged— I thence went and called upon Mr Laval; he was not at home, and I went to Mr Harris’s— He mentioned to me his intention of sending his nephew home to America, by the way of England, and asked me to obtain for him a Courier’s Passport; for which I promised him that I would apply. While I was there, Mr Laval sent me word that he had returned home, and I called on him again. I had drawn his Certificate according to a form which he sent me; being the same that had heretofore been used by the French Consul— But it purported that Mr Laval’s Acte de Naissance, had been presented to me; and I accordingly asked him to shew it me— He said he had given it to Mr Lesseps who had not returned it— I observed that I could not then Certify that it had been presented to me— He thought those were mere words of form, and that I might certify, in Confidence upon his Statement— In the form Mr Lesseps had used those words were underscored and minuted as indispensible— I told Mr Laval that my Confidence in his assertion was perfect, but it could not justify me in certifying what was not the fact. I would either omit the words, or insert in their stead “deposited at the French Consulate in this City[”]— He preferred the latter, and we appointed seven in the Evening for me to call upon him with the new Certificate— At seven I accordingly went with it— And he signed it— I left it with him to be signed by four witnesses, as the french Law requires— It is for an annuity which his mother receives upon his life— Madame Laval was present, and Count Maistre was there— They are to go in five or six days— They both appear to be much dejected— They are fugitives from one of the most magnificent Establishments in St: Petersburg.— A house where Splendour and Hospitality went hand in hand— They are going with a family of small children; literally they know not where; and to return they know not when— Madame de Betancourt and all her Children went the day before yesterday— They go to England— We shall have scarcely an acquaintance left.— Baron Blome paid me a long visit— He is much out of health, and no less out of Spirits. He thinks the Swedes are going to attack the Island of Zeeland; and he is very apprehensive they will succeed in taking it.— He says they have not the shadow of a complaint against Denmark, and that it will be an attack more treacherous and profligate than that upon Spain.— He appears fully convinced that Kutuzoff had really won the Battle of Borodino, though the world will never believe it— I do not yet believe it myself— The Baron however gives credit to all the stories they circulate here, many of which are without foundation— Mrs Adams was yesterday quite unwell, and has been the whole of this day confined to her bed.

10. Mrs Adams was extremely ill the whole Night, and I was twice up.— She was this day a little better, and left her Chamber. Mrs Krehmer, with her daughter Sally and her Son George came after dinner, and went with Catherine and Charles to the Theatre— We had an Evening visit from Prince Koslofsky. Notwithstanding his appointment as Minister to Sardinia he still retains his desire of going to America— He says he shall ask for the place there, if Mr Daschkoff should come away; and that if his Government will send him to America he will stipulate with them to stay there all his life; and never to ask for any thing else. He expects to go for Cagliari in ten or twelve days; he goes through Sweden and England; and has the Emperor’s permission to stay one month in London.— I employed the day chiefly in writing; but in the Evening read several Chapters in Gisborne’s Enquiry into the duties of the female sex.

11. Mr Montréal called upon me this morning.— The Government has been so long without publishing any intelligence of any importance from the armies, that a variety of unfavourable reports have sprung up in the room of real information. I suppose all of them to be unfounded— I took Charles out to walk with me before dinner— Read prayers, and Sterne’s Sermon upon the House of Mourning and the House of Feasting.— I had read one by Foster upon the same text, three weeks since— The argument is nearly
the same in both— But Sterne’s manner is more lively and affecting. In this Sermon particularly there are appearances of levity, both at the beginning and end of the Discourse, too inconsistent with its own drift and purpose— He begins by a trick upon his Auditory, and upon his reader— By seeming flatly to deny his text, as soon as he has given it out. Afterwards you perceive it is not the preacher who denies, but a supposed collocutor with him; a man of the world who is to argue the point against him; and whom he no otherwise introduces than by repeating his part of the imaginary dialogue, as well as the preacher’s replies.— This is a sort of theatrical artifice for which the pulpit was not the proper place— At the end there is not only an admission which seems to weaken much of what had been said concerning the uses of sorrow, but a sarcasm upon gravity perfectly misplaced; and apparently introduced to excite the hearer’s laughter— The Body of the Sermon is serious, forcible, animated, pathetic—in short an admirable and unanswerable vindication of the text— The first and last sentences are fit only for a Harlequin—the rest of the Sermon is worthy of a Saint and a Martyr— Such are many of Sterne’s Discourses— I also read Sermons 9 and 10. Vol. 9. of the English preacher— One a Charity Sermon; upon Liberality—the other a Fast Sermon, against Avarice.

12. Morning visits from Mr Harris, and from Mr Hall with a Mr Rogers of Salem, lately from Archangel— I received an answer from Mr Gourieff the Minister of the finances, concerning the affair of Captain Knox— That he had been discharged from further prosecution; and I received also a letter from Mr Hazard, mentioning that Captain Knox had escaped with his vessel.— A letter from Mr Russell of 9. September informs me that he had his Passports and in three days was to go and embark at Plymouth— And that the British Government had rejected a proposition he had been authorised to make to them, for a suspension of hostilities— I employed the day in writing and walking; and the Evening in hearing Charles read and playing with him. Mr Smith dined abroad.

13. I dismissed Louis Aubin from my service— I took him in the place of Thomas Baker, and have found him nothing better— I have now determined to make the trial of Pierre Ouvré, who has served us three years as a footman, and who has been the best man-servant I have met with in this Country— I rose this morning as the day was dawning, and walked the round which I so constantly followed last Winter and Spring— A Mr Jackson of Newbury-Port called upon me— He is going to America and took of me some letters and despatches— Charles walked with me before dinner.— In the Evening, after hearing him and playing with him I read a few pages in Clarke’s travels—and some English papers lent by Captain Guedes to Mr Smith.

14. Mr Jackson called upon me again this morning for a Passport, which I gave him; and also another dispatch for the Secretary of State, and a letter for Mr Everett— I walked before Breakfast, and passed through two or three Streets, which I had not seen before— After noon I rode to the shops and walked home.— Mr Smith dined with Mr Slade— In the Evening I read a few pages in Clarke’s travels—

15. I received this morning a Note from Count Romanzoff requesting me to call on him at his house on the Quay, at seven O’Clock in the Evening.— I accordingly went; and he said he wished to consult me as to the manner of sending to the United States dispatches to Mr Daschkoff, containing the proposal of the Emperor Alexander’s Mediation, between the United States and Great-Britain— That with regard to my dispatching a Courier directly, he had spoken to the English Ambassador, to ask if he would furnish a passport or paper to secure such a person from being taken by the British—which Lord Cathcart answered he would readily do, provided the Courier should go by the way of England— But the Count said he had replied that he could not propose to me to agree to such a Condition— I thought it not advisable on my part to agree to it; but mentioned to the Count that I should in a few days apply to him for a Courier’s Passport, for an American whom I should charge with my dispatches, and who would take his for Mr Daschkoff, if he thought proper to trust them to this conveyance— He said his dispatches were all ready, and the Passport could be furnished as soon as I should ask for it— He asked if there would not be an opportunity to send, direct to the United States from Archangel— I told him I believed it was too late. He said upon reflection he believed it was, and it reminded him of an answer of Admiral Tchichagoff after a visit he had made to Archangel, to the Emperor, who asked him how long he had stayed there. He said he had spent the whole Summer there— The Emperor, knowing his absence had been very short, said with some surprize, how so?—the whole Summer!—three days, Sire, said the Admiral— I told the Count that I should probably ask for the Passport, towards the close of the next week— The Courier would probably be obliged to go through England— If he was stopp’d
the English Government might perhaps read the despatches—for that, I could not answer— The Count said that as to his dispatches, it would not be of any consequence—they would only read over again in the identical words the same proposition that had been made to themselves— I asked him if he had any good news from the armies; he said none of any consequence— Nothing but what was in the Bulletin’s— He enquired concerning a report circulating here that a suspension of hostilities had already taken place between U.S. and England— I mentioned my information from Mr Russell, directly to the contrary; and that a proposition made by him to that effect had been rejected by the English Government— He said this would not discourage him from the proposition of the Russian Mediation, but on the contrary would rather make him more earnest in the proposal; from the confirmed opinion, that an indirect negotiation, would not be liable to the mutual irritations which had attended the direct attempts— He also mentioned the Account he had seen in the newspapers that the American troops had taken the town of Sandwich in Canada— I told him that was nothing more than that they had entered the Province— There had been no fighting.— I was with the Count about half an hour, and spoke to him of Mr Fulton’s letter to me, with his wish to obtain an exclusive privilege for constructing steam-boats in Russia— I asked him if exclusive privileges were granted here to the inventors of useful machines—he said they sometimes were; not by a general law, but by special grant from the Emperor, of which there was one recent example. I explained to him the nature of Mr Fulton’s Steam-boats—the very advantageous experience of them in America, and my own perswasion that the introduction of them between St: Petersburg and Cronstadt would be not only useful but important to the Commerce of this City— He asked if I had any Memoir upon the subject from the inventor; which I could give him, to shew to the Emperor, after consultation with the Minister of the Marine. I told him I had only a letter from Mr Fulton himself, and I would send him an abstract of his proposals in that— The Count appeared well disposed to favour an application of this sort, and asked some questions respecting the operation of our patent Laws— As whether they did not give frequent occasion to litigation, as to the fact of a new invention— How the claims to Patents were examined, and upon what conditions they were granted— He asked also whether Mr Fulton’s steam-boat, could stem rapids in rivers, as well as currents— I said I believed not— That he said, would be a most important invention indeed to this Country, where owing to a few very insignificant falls of water, they were obliged to break up, and burn for common fuel all the boats that brought merchandize down their rivers.— After leaving the Count I passed the remainder of the Evening at home.

16. When I was last Evening with Count Romanzoff, I supposed that Mr Jackson was gone, and that I should not have an opportunity to send the dispatches before young Mr Harris, who is to go the last of next week—but on calling this morning at Mr Jackson’s lodgings I learnt that he was not gone— He and Captain Sargent afterwards separately called upon me— Their intention was to go down to Cronstadt to-morrow morning— I proposed to them to wait one or two days longer, to which they agreed, and I wrote a Note to Count Romanzoff, requesting a Courier’s Passport for Mr Jackson, and offering to transmit by him the Count’s dispatches for Mr Daschkoff— Mr Tilden called here with Captain Sargent, and I had also a morning visit from Mr Hurd— I called also at Mr Harris’s, to enquire whether the time for his nephew’s departure was precisely fixed; but he was not at home.— I was troubled all the morning with a severe head ache, but was engaged all the time in writing— In the Evening I heard Charles read, and played with him to teach him numeration. Mrs Adams now hears him generally in the morning.

17. I received this morning from Count Romanzoff the Passport for Mr Jackson, and packets for Mr Daschkoff and for Count Pahlen at Rio Janeyro.— Mr Jackson did not however come for them this day— The wind is west; so that they cannot sail from Cronstadt untill a change— It rained almost the whole day; so that excepting my walk before Breakfast I was confined to the house.
Mr Harris junr: paid us an Evening visit, but I was engaged in writing and did not see him— I wrote to Count Romanzoff, concerning Mr Fulton’s business— Mr Smith went to the theatre.

18. Mr Jackson being still detained by adverse winds, I employed much of this day in writing letters to send by him to America— I read prayers, and Sterne’s third Sermon—that upon the parable of the good Samaritan— An exhortation to benevolence— It is not liable to the same objection as that on the House of Mourning— There is no levity or buffoonery in it— But all is grave, earnest and pathetic— It is however like that quite dramatic— The Priest, the Levite, and the Samaritan are characters, and he gives Soliloquies to the traveller and the Samaritan— I read also, Sermons 11. and 12. Vol. 9. of the English preacher on Patriotism; and on false and true Pleasure— False pleasure is luxury, public amusements, gaming &c—and true pleasure is Virtue and Charity.— Walked before Breakfast and before dinner— The rainy season has commenced—later than usual.

19. Mr Jackson came this morning, and I gave him the Courier’s Passports, and the dispatches sent me by Count Romanzoff, with my own— I afterwards called at his lodgings, and gave him some more private letters, with some from Coll: Rapatel, which he brought me and requested me to send by him. I wrote also to the Chevalier Navarro, who is now Portuguese Chargé d’Affairs at Cagliari in Sardinia, and I took the letter to Prince Koslofsky’s lodgings, to take leave of him and ask him to take charge of the letter— He was not at home, and I left the letter with his servant— I stop’d at Count Romanzoff’s door, and left a letter for him— I walked home— In the Evening I played with Charles and read Gisborne, on the duties of the female sex— Mr Rapatel told me that he had just left Baron Armfeldt who informed him that a Courier arrived in the Night, who left the Russian great army engaged in a general Battle with the French— He thinks that the French army, are about to abandon Moscow, and retire back into Poland— He himself is going to Sweden— He says the Emperor had intended to send him to the great army; but he had requested to be employed, either upon this expedition from Sweden, or at General Tormassoff’s army; which is opposed chiefly to Austrians, and Saxons— He has a scruple against active service in opposition to Frenchmen— Mr Harris also called upon me— His nephew will be ready to go next Sunday— I mentioned to him my idea, of asking Count Romanzoff, for a Courier’s Passport as bearer of his despatches to Mr Daschkoff; as it might afford him more certain protection from British capture than if he went as an American Courier.— He was gratified with the proposal— Mr Harris told me that Dr Creighton had mentioned to him, that Sir Robert Wilson when he was here had said to him at his table, that Mr Perceval just before his Death had assured him Sir Robert Wilson, that it was his intention to make War against the United States of America, and that he had good grounds for the expectation that it would end in the restoration of the British authority, over the Northern Provinces of the American Union.

20. I walked before Breakfast this morning; and employed the day untill dinner time in writing—the Evening in teaching Charles, and in reading Dr: Gisborne.— A continual rain confined me to the house, and we had no visitors— I read also part of Lancaster’s account of his school; and his observations upon the efficacy of emulation to make children learn rapidly— I find the want of it with Charles; and also now of regular school hours— The omission of one day never fails to raise in him a reluctance to resume reading for the next, and my own avocations frequently interfere indispensably with his lessons— He reads both French and English with little difficulty, but now wants continual and uninterrupted practice to guard him from bad habits of pronunciation, and bad tones of reading; at his present stage of proficiency it is surprizing, what a propensity there is to fall into such bad habits, and what an obstinate and persevering attention is necessary for the teacher to prevent them from taking root and becoming irremediable.

21. After my morning walk I was again confined at home by constant rain the remainder of the day. Wrote a Note to Count Romanzoff to ask to see him, and received his answer appointing to-morrow Morning at 11. O’Clock— Mr Harris spent great part of the Evening with us. He says that Mr Laval told him that he had been informed by Mr Balacheff, the Minister of the Police, that since Prince Volkonsky’s return from the army, the Emperor had less confidence in Marshal Kutusoff than he had before— That Murat had made some proposals tending to a Negotiation for Peace, which, if the Russian army should be defeated, the Emperor Alexander would perhaps incline to consider— That the Peace party about the Court was growing stronger— That the English Ambassador, instead of treating directly with Count Romanzoff, was endeavouring to obtain access to the Emperor through the medium of Count Tolstoy.— That the
joint Swedish and Russian Expedition was certainly and indefinitely postponed— At all Events not to take effect this year— Almost all this information appears to me extremely questionable— Prince Volkonsky is one of the Emperor’s Aid-de-Camp Generals; and was sent off to the Army, very suddenly, on the Emperor’s hearing of the surrender of Moscow— He returned four or five days ago— It was rumoured when he went that he was sent to feel the way for negotiation— Now Mr Balacheff says that proposals have been made by Murat— It is more probable that he was sent to inspect and Report to the Emperor, the real state of the army, and of Affairs— And it is not unlikely that he has returned with accounts differing essentially from Kutusoff’s Reports. The rest of this news must be taken with caution.

22. I called at 11 O’Clock this morning upon Count Romanzoff, and told him that young Harris was going to America, and that I proposed sending by him duplicates of my last despatches to the American Government. I asked him if he would by the same occasion send duplicates of his despatches to Mr Daschkoff, and on that account give him a Passport as a Messenger despatched by him— This the Count said he could not do— Mr Harris being an American, he could not give him a Passport as a Russian Courier, and if he should the English would pay no regard to it— He had already found himself engaged in a discussion with the British Ambassador on the subject of Passports— He had asked the Ambassador for his Visa to one—the Ambassador had answered in the most obliging manner possible, as to the forms—but had been quand au fond, assez sec. He had offered very readily to give his endorsement; but observed at the same time, that the English Cruizers, might pay no attention to it; as they acted under their Instructions from home; governed by the English laws— But the Count said he would send duplicates of his despatches to Mr Daschkoff, by Mr Harris, and in his Courier’s Passport would have it inserted that he was also bearer of his despatches to the Russian Minister in America— The Count himself had in our first Conversation concerning the Mediation proposed to me to give the Messenger I should send, a Passport as a Russian Courier, and it was on that suggestion that I asked it for Mr Harris— But the Count then did not know the difficulties started by the British Ambassador— Perhaps the insertion which he offered may answer the purpose as well as a formal Passport, and I readily accepted the offer— After I came home, young Mr Harris called upon me, and I informed him of what the Chancellor had said to me— I passed the rest of the day occupied as usual— In the Evening I finished reading Gisborne on the Duties of the female sex— A sober and moral discourse; containing many sensible remarks, and much judicious advice— It deals perhaps too much in mere generalities— The tone is moderate, the style simple but not inelegant. Being altogether didactic it is cold; but it is perfectly intelligible, and generally correct in principle.

23. About 2 this morning I was awakened by Charles, and slept no more— Between 5 and 6 I rose; and immediately walked an hour and a half, untill day-light— It is the first morning this Season that I have walked before day.— I wrote a Note to Count Romanzoff to ask for young Harris’s Passport; which he sent me together with the duplicate dispatches for Count Pahlen, and Mr Daschkoff about two hours after.— Mr Harris the Consul called upon me, and desired me to obtain also a Passport for his nephew, from Count Löwenhielm;—that he may pass without interruption through Sweden— Mr Lewis spent the Evening with us.— He shewed me a letter he has received from Mr Thomas Willing at Gothenburg— It appears there is no prospect of a Peace between the United States and England— I employed most of the day in writing.

24. I called this morning upon Count Löwenhielm at the Hotel de l’Europe, to ask him for a Passport for young Mr Harris, to go through Sweden; which he promised he would send me— I found the Marquis de Paulucci with him; an Officer who has been of some note the last Spring and Summer— The Count told me the news, which he said was not a little important. Wittgenstein had taken Polotzk by storm—two thousand frenchmen killed—and Winzingerode was at Moscow; and his Cossacks fought with the French in the Streets of Moscow— Wittgenstein would now cross the Dwina and form his junction with the armies of Tormassoff and Tchitchagoff, and then—je prévois des douleurs—(to Bonaparte) The Count is as sangwine as he was last Spring; he thinks the destruction of the Emperor Napoleon and his army inevitable. Making every allowance for the exaggerations
of prejudice and passion, it is obvious they are in great and imminent danger; and their inaction so long after the occupation of Moscow, is very unlike the former practice of Napoleon.— Paulucci said that he had committed the same imprudence in 1797, and had extricated himself from it by the Peace, which he was compelled to ask, and to which Austria then assented. But for that he was then perdu sans ressource— I have often heard this before— But he had then, and has now his greatest of all resources—a Battle— His fortunes and existence are staked upon that; and he has so long abused the favours of Fortune, that she will certainly finish by jilting him— Or rather Providence, (such is my belief) after using him for the purposes he is destined to answer, will exhibit him like another invader of Russia, “to point a moral or adorn a tale.”— I called upon Baron Blome, Captain Guedes and Mr Fisher, but neither of them was at home— Mr Redwood and Mr Tilden paid us an Evening visit— The Ladies were at the Theatre.

25. Received a Notification from the Grand Master of the Ceremonies, of a Court, to be held to-morrow at the Winter-Palace at Noon; it being the Empress Mother’s Birth-day— And at the same time a Te Deum for the victory of the General of Cavalry Count Wittgenstein over the French commanded by Marshal Gouvion St: Cyr, and for the taking by storm of the fortified City of Polotzk— I had visits from Mr Montreal, and from Mr Laval, who has postponed his departure for five or six days longer— He is not quite so sangwine as Löwenhielm, that the French army will inevitably be destroyed: but he thinks the present prospects of the Russian Cause superb— He still dreads the genius and resources of Napoleon, more than they deserve— The accounts are so numerous and so uniform, that his army is famishing; that he has proposed to Kutuzoff by Count Lauriston an armistice, that his retreat through Smolensk is impossible, that they are no longer mere rumours. Kutuzoff has received a reinforcement of 24 regiments, 18000 men— Don Cossacks— The Novogrod armament 80000 men are rapidly advancing to Moscow from this side— Many of Napoleon’s Couriers, and Mails with letters have been intercepted; all complaining that they are in want of every thing— One from the Bavarian General to the King of Bavaria, in which he complains that the allies are not allowed to forage, and that they are starved that the french soldiers may be fed— Kutuzoff has reorganized the army, and filled up the vacancies in the Regiments, from the Moscow Armament— The answer to the proposal for an armistice, was a mere reference to the Emperor Alexander’s declaration at Wilna—that he would not make Peace while an armed Enemy should remain on the Russian Territory.— Such is the change from despondency to confidence effected by the storm of Polotzk— I read prayers and Sterne’s Sermon 4. On Self-knowledge—Nathan and David— Also the Sermons 14 and 15. Vol. 9. of the English preacher— On consistency as a Christian duty— And on the joy of Parents in virtuous Children— This finishes the Compilation— I likewise read some Chapters in Gisborne’s Moral Philosophy— He attacks Paley’s principle of general expediency as the standard of morality—I believe with good reason— Charles is quite unwell.

26. At twelve O’Clock, Mr Smith and myself attended at the Winter Palace, according to the Notification. The Te Deum commenced between one and two— There was no Court held after it, notwithstanding the Notice— The new diplomatic Corps were there— Lord Cathcart, the British Ambassador with his suite of seven persons. The duke de Serra-Capriola with his Son; Mr Zea, as Spanish Minister; and Captain Guedes as Chargé d’Affairs from Portugal— Count Löwenhielm as Minister from Sweden, with the Russian ribband of St: Anne of the first Class which the Emperor gave him at Abo. Mr Brandel as Secretary of Legation— Baron Blome and Mr Krabbe, from Denmark, and Count Maistre from Sardinia, were with us the only remnants of the former Corps— There was a Comte de Noailles there; an emigrant lately from England— Lord Walpole the Secretary of the British Embassy, asked Lord Cathcart to introduce him to me, which he did; and I had some Conversation with him about Architecture, and Sculpture; Guarenghi’s buildings and the Statue of Peter the Great— The Te Deum was like all the others I have heard in the chapel— Baron Blome told me he hoped the expedition against the island of Zealand was postponed; but he did not venture yet to be confident— After we returned home I walked with Charles, whose state of health distresses me more than I can express— Met Messrs. Willing, Redwood, Fisher and Plummer—who all told me the story of the capture of the British frigate, Guerrière, by our Frigate Constitution— I considered it as a joke, invented by some of the Americans here—and had indeed been told that it was— In the Evening Mr Harris and his nephew called upon us, and spent a couple of hours with us— They had called upon me in the morning and I had delivered my own dispatches and letters to young Mr Harris, together with those of Count Romanzoff for Mr Daschkoff— Admiral Bentinck offered to take any message from me to Madame de Stael.

27. About Noon this day the Report of Cannon from the fortress, announced that important and pleasing information from the armies, had been received; about half an hour afterwards Mr Harris, the Consul came in— He had just come from Count Romanzoff’s, where he had been with his nephew, upon a visit of taking leave. The news was a great victory of Marshal Kutuzoff, over the king of Naples, Murat; and the retaking of Moscow, by General Winzingerode’s Corps— Though in atchieving it, Winzingerode was himself taken prisoner— In the Evening I received from the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies a Notification to attend a Te Deum to morrow morning, at the Kazan Church, on Account of these Events— The City was illuminated at Night— Mr Harris junr: came and took leave, and I gave him my last Letters— I walked with Charles to the Summer Gardens and in them, before dinner; and I spent the Evening in amusing, and teaching him.— Mr Harris lent me an English Courier, of 6. October which he had borrowed from Count Romanzoff, containing a confirmation of the capture of the Guerriere frigate; but with it an account of the surrender of General Hull and his army; and of the taking of Fort Detroit by the British— It would be useless, and the attempt would be vain to express my sensations upon this Event. There are scarcely any details of the affair given— The honour of my Country!— Oh! God! suffer it not to go unredeemed!

28. I wrote this morning another letter, to send by Mr Harris junr:— He was already gone to Cronstadt; but I sent it down to him by Mr Kittera, who goes this Evening, and by whom I also sent triplicates of my late dispatches. Mr Smith took them over to Mr Lewis’s, where Mr Kittera lodges. About Noon I went with Mr Smith to the Kazan Church, and attended the Te Deum for Marshal Kutuzoff’s, or rather for General Bennigsen’s victory, and for the deliverance of Moscow— The Duke of Serra-Capriola, and Baron Armfeldt were in the highest exultation of glory. Armfeldt had a letter from his Son, who was with Bennigsen at the Battle; written the day after, in all the insolence of victory— Armfeldt went about reading it to every body who would hear him— Without moving from where I stood I heard him read it seven times— Prince Plato Zuboff, the last favourite of Catherine, was also there— I had seen him at Berlin in 1797 and 1798— I did not know him again, and asked who he was— He has been in disgrace ever since the present Emperor’s accession, but his Estates in Poland, where he resided being now overrun, he is again admitted at Court. Count Romanzoff apologized to me for having permitted Mr Harris yesterday to take to me a paper with bad news— I congratulated him on the occasion of the Te Deum, which he said it was to be hoped would be followed by important consequences; and especially that it would correct some opinions concerning the Russians which had been industriously disseminated. I suppose he alluded to the reputation of the Military skill of their Generals— The music of the Te Deum was remarkably fine— After it was finished the Emperor the Empress, and Empress Mother, the Grand Dukes Constantine, Nicholas and Michael, and the Grand-Duchess Ann made their prostrations and adoration to the miraculous image of the Virgin— When the Emperor left the Church to return to the Palace he was greeted with three shouts by the crowd of People who surrounded the Church.— The City was illuminated again in the Evening.

29. I went with Catherine and Charles immediately after dinner, to Mr Krehmer’s at Ochta, where we spent the Evening, returned home about 10 at Night. Mr Krehmer told me there was a further report received this day from Count Wittgenstein— That the Corps of Gouvion St: Cyr, united with that of Macdonald had been pursued, overtaken, and almost totally destroyed. Mr Krehmer invited us to dine with him next Wednesday, to meet Sir Francis d’Ivernois who has expressed a wish to be acquianted with me.

30. Received a letter from Mr R. G. Beasley, London, enclosing the Courier of 6. October—the Seal announces him as Agent for American Prisoners of War— He refers to previous letters of 26. and 29. Septr: which I have not received. I had morning visits from Mr Harris and Mr Lewis— Mr Redwood passed the Evening here— Young Harris sailed from Cronstadt the same morning that he went down, and has had fair wind and weather ever since— The cold East-winds are beginning.

31. I walked nearly two hours this morning before breakfast— The weather was remarkably fine— The sky clear as crystal, and the Sun rose in all his beauty and magnificence— But there was a cold East wind, and half an hour after I returned home, I found myself seized with a rhumatism about the loins, which obliged me immediately to assume my winter underdress— It did not however suffice to remove the complaint— I walked however again before dinner— Mr Stanwood called on me in the Evening; just arrived from England— He brought me several letters, packets of Newspapers; and the books for which I sent by Mr Woodward— The Ladies went to the Theatre.

Day. During this month I have risen usually about 6 O’Clock— Sometimes by 5—seldom if ever so late as 7. walked an hour and a half. Read the Bible and journalize untill 10.— Breakfast— Hear Charles; see visitors and write untill 4. p.m. walk an hour— dine at 5. play with Charles, and teach him two hours— read one or two more— From 10 to 11. is the hour for bed.
